banner.title: TP TEDLive 9/28/23
banner.mainContentHeadline: Experience the TEDWomen conference from anywhere
banner.mainContent: Don't miss out! Be one of the first to see our powerful new talks.

fields.title: TED Tech Jun 12 Tablet Portrait Talks (3)
TED Tech Jun 12 Tablet Landscape Talks (5)

videoData.title: Adventures of an asteroid hunter

recommendations.blurb: Check out these resources on asteroid hunting, curated by Carrie Nugent.

recItems.blurb: The NASA office concerned with potentially hazardous objects (PHOs), which are defined as the asteroids or comets whose orbits get within 0.05 AU (an astronomical unit, the average distance between the Earth and the Sun) of Earth's orbit and are above a certain size. They are responsible for the early detection of PHOs, tracking and characterizing PHOs, providing timely and accurate communications about PHOs and coordinating the US government planning for a response in the case of an actual impact threat.
recItems.headline: NASA's Planetary Defense Coordination Office
recItems.label: EXPLORE

recItems.blurb: Learn about near-Earth asteroids and comets, and see which objects will be making close approaches to Earth.
recItems.headline: Center for Near-Earth Object Studies
recItems.label: EXPLORE

recItems.blurb: This is the designated archive for positional measurements of asteroids and comets. The Minor Planet Center also determines orbits and decides when a new asteroid has been discovered. The front page has latest stats on asteroid discoveries.
recItems.headline: Minor Planet Center
recItems.label: EXPLORE

recItems.blurb: A United Nations-sanctioned organization of asteroid observers, orbit computers, physical property specialists and other scientists and communications experts that study near-Earth objects.
recItems.headline: International Asteroid Warning Network
recItems.label: EXPLORE

recItems.blurb:
Looking for a glimpse into current space research? Each week on this podcast I share a drink with a scientist or engineer who explores space, and we chat about their work.

Episodes having to do with asteroids can be found [here](https://www.listentospacepod.com/episodes/?tag=Asteroids#show-archive).
recItems.headline: Spacepod
recItems.label: LISTEN

takeAction.blurb: **Petition your congressional representatives to support NASA.** More than 95 percent of near-Earth asteroids have been discovered by NASA-funded surveys. If you feel strongly about this and are a US citizen, you can reach out to your representatives and express your support for NASA to continue the search.

nodes.whoTheyAre: Carrie Nugent is part of a team that uses NASA's NEOWISE telescope to search the skies for and catalog asteroids.
nodes.whyListen:
Dr. Carrie Nugent is an asteroid hunter who works with a small team to discover and study asteroids at Caltech/IPAC. She earned her PhD in Geophysics and Space Physics from UCLA in 2013 and is a 2016 TED Fellow. Specializing in thermophysical modeling, Nugent uses observations from the space-based infrared telescope NEOWISE to better understand asteroid surfaces. Asteroid 8801 Nugent was named in her honor.

In her free time, Nugent hosts and produces Spacepod. On this weekly podcast, she invites astronomers, planetary scientists and engineers to sit, share a drink and tell the world about their corner of the cosmos.

Nugent is the author of the TED Book, Asteroid Hunters.

videoData.description: TED Fellow Carrie Nugent is an asteroid hunter -- part of a group of scientists working to discover and catalog our oldest and most numerous cosmic neighbors. Why keep an eye out for asteroids? In this short, fact-filled talk, Nugent explains how their awesome impacts have shaped our planet, and how finding them at the right time could mean nothing less than saving life on Earth.
videoData.socialDescription: TED Fellow Carrie Nugent is an asteroid hunter -- part of a group of scientists working to discover and catalog our oldest and most numerous cosmic neighbors. Why keep an eye out for asteroids? In this short, fact-filled talk, Nugent explains how their awesome impacts have shaped our planet, and how finding them at the right time could mean nothing less than saving life on Earth.

cues.text: I am holding something remarkably old.
It is older than any human artifact,
older than life on Earth,

older than the continents
and the oceans between them.

This was formed
over four billion years ago
in the earliest days of the solar system
while the planets were still forming.

This rusty lump of nickel and iron
may not appear special,
but when it is cut open ...

you can see that it is different
from earthly metals.

This pattern reveals metallic crystals
that can only form out in space

where molten metal
can cool extremely slowly,
a few degrees every million years.

This was once part
of a much larger object,

one of millions left over
after the planets formed.
We call these objects asteroids.

Asteroids are our oldest
and most numerous cosmic neighbors.

This graphic shows near-Earth asteroids
orbiting around the Sun,
shown in yellow,
and swinging close to the Earth's orbit,
shown in blue.

The sizes of the Earth, Sun and asteroids
have been greatly exaggerated
so you can see them clearly.

Teams of scientists across the globe
are searching for these objects,
discovering new ones every day,
steadily mapping near-Earth space.
Much of this work is funded by NASA.

I think of the search for these asteroids
as a giant public works project,

but instead of building a highway,
we're charting outer space,

building an archive
that will last for generations.

These are the 1,556 near-Earth asteroids
discovered just last year.

And these are all of the known
near-Earth asteroids,
which at last count was 13,733.
Each one has been imaged, cataloged

and had its path
around the Sun determined.

Although it varies
from asteroid to asteroid,

the paths of most asteroids
can be predicted for dozens of years.

And the paths of some asteroids can be
predicted with incredible precision.

For example, scientists
at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory

predicted where the asteroid Toutatis
was going to be four years in advance
to within 30 kilometers.
In those four years,
Toutatis traveled 8.5 billion kilometers.
That's a fractional precision
(Laughter)

Now, the reason I have
this beautiful asteroid fragment
is because, like all neighbors,
asteroids sometimes drop by unexpectedly.
(Laughter)
Three years ago today,

a small asteroid exploded
over the city of Chelyabinsk, Russia.
That object was about 19 meters across,
or about as big as a convenience store.

Objects of this size hit the Earth
every 50 years or so.
66 million years ago,
a much larger object hit the Earth,
causing a massive extinction.

75 percent of plant
and animal species were lost,
including, sadly, the dinosaurs.

That object was
about 10 kilometers across,

and 10 kilometers is roughly
the cruising altitude of a 747 jet.
So the next time you're in an airplane,

snag a window seat, look out
and imagine a rock so enormous
that resting on the ground,
it just grazes your wingtip.

It's so wide that it takes your plane
one full minute to fly past it.

That's the size of the asteroid
that hit the Earth.
It has only been within my lifetime

that asteroids have been considered
a credible threat to our planet.

And since then, there's been
a focused effort underway
to discover and catalog these objects.

I am lucky enough
to be part of this effort.

I'm part of a team of scientists
that use NASA's NEOWISE telescope.

Now, NEOWISE was not
designed to find asteroids.

It was designed to orbit the earth
and look far beyond our solar system

to seek out the coldest stars
and the most luminous galaxies.

And it did that very well
for its designed lifetime of seven months.

But today, six years later,
it's still going.

We've repurposed it
to discover and study asteroids.

And although it's
a wonderful little space robot,
these days it's kind of like a used car.

The cryogen that used to refrigerate
its sensors is long gone,

so we joke that
its air-conditioning is broken.

It's got 920 million miles
on the odometer,
but it still runs great

and reliably takes a photograph
of the sky every 11 seconds.

It's taken 23 photos
since I began speaking to you.
One of the reasons NEOWISE is so valuable

is that it sees the sky
in the thermal infrared.

That means that instead of seeing
the sunlight that asteroids reflect,
NEOWISE sees the heat that they emit.

This is a vital capability
since some asteroids are as dark as coal

and can be difficult or impossible
to spot with other telescopes.

But all asteroids, light or dark,
shine brightly for NEOWISE.

Astronomers are using
every technique at their disposal
to discover and study asteroids.
In 2010, a historic milestone was reached.

The community, together, discovered
over 90 percent of asteroids
bigger than one kilometer across --

objects capable
of massive destruction to Earth.
But the job's not done yet.

An object 140 meters or bigger
could decimate a medium-sized country.

So far, we've only found
25 percent of those.

We must keep searching the sky
for near-Earth asteroids.

We are the only species
able to understand calculus
or build telescopes.
We know how to find these objects.
This is our responsibility.

If we found a hazardous asteroid
with significant early warning,
we could nudge it out of the way.

Unlike earthquakes, hurricanes
or volcanic eruptions,

an asteroid impact
can be precisely predicted
and prevented.

What we need to do now
is map near-Earth space.
We must keep searching the sky.
Thank you.
(Applause)

footnotes.annotation:
"This was formed over four billion years ago ..."

The particular meteorite I'm holding is a piece of Muonionalusta. Scientists studying other pieces of that meteorite put its age at 4.57 billion years.

Blichert-Toft et al., "The early formation of the IVA iron meteorite parent body." *Earth and Planetary Science Letters,* 296, 469-480. 2010.

"This pattern reveals metallic crystals that can only form out in space, where molten metal can cool extremely slowly -- a few degrees every million years."

The technical term is Widmanstätten pattern, and there’s a [great Wikipedia page](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Widmanst%C3%A4tten_pattern) on it. To learn more about how that cooling rate was determined, see, for example, Wood, J. A, "The Cooling Rates and Parent Planets of Several Iron Meteorites." *Icarus,* 3, 429-459. 1964.

"This graphic shows near-Earth asteroids orbiting around our Sun …"

Near-Earth asteroids are defined as asteroids whose perihelion (closest approach to the Sun) is less than 1.3 AU (where an AU is an Astronomical Unit, or the average distance between the Earth and the Sun).

"The sizes of the Earth, Sun and asteroids have been greatly exaggerated ..."

Asteroids are so small, and the space between them is so vast, that it is always challenging to depict them accurately in graphics. If anyone does have a clever idea of how to show this better, drop me [a line](www.crnugent.com/contact).

"Teams of scientists across the globe are searching for these objects, discovering new ones every day, steadily mapping near-Earth space."

Many people work on discovering asteroids. I play a small role in just one of five major asteroid-hunting programs.

"Much of this work is funded by NASA."

There is a vibrant international community of scientists studying asteroids, and tracking asteroids is a worldwide effort, requiring telescopes located all across the globe. However, here I’m talking about asteroid discovery, and more than 95 percent of near-Earth asteroids were discovered by NASA-funded surveys. For more, see [here](https://www.nasa.gov/planetarydefense/overview)

"These are the 1,556 near-Earth asteroids that were discovered last year. And these are all of the known near-Earth asteroids, which at last count was 13,733."

This talk was given February 15th, 2016, so I'm saying that 1,556 near-Earth asteroids were discovered in 2015. 13,733 near-Earth asteroids were known a few days before I gave the talk (I needed a little time to memorize the number).

Here's the updated numbers: in 2016, 1,893 near-Earth asteroids were discovered. As I write this the total number of known near-Earth asteroids is 15,856 -- but as asteroid hunters discover new ones every day, that's going to be out of date by the time you read this. To check the latest stats, see [here](www.minorplanetcenter.net)

"Each one has been imaged, cataloged and had its path around the Sun determined."

Asteroids are discovered by examining images of the sky. The Minor Planet Center determines orbits from the asteroid's position in the sky and keeps track of every asteroid. For more, see [here](http://minorplanetcenter.net/).

"For example, the scientists at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory predicted where the asteroid Toutatis was going to be four years in advance, to within 30 kilometers."

Scientist Jon Giorgini did this work and suggested this particular example. Toutatis’ 2012 range (distance from Earth to asteroid) was predicted in 2008 to within a kilometer. I quoted (on Jon’s advice) the three-dimensional difference in predicted and observed position, which was 30 kilometers.

The asteroid that caused this fireball was about 19 meters across, or about as big as a convenience store.

Kring, D. A., and Boslough, M, "Chelyabinsk: Portrait of an asteroid airburst." *Physics Today*, 67(9), 32. 2014.

"Objects of this size hit the Earth every 50 years or so."

See Figure 3 in Brown et al., "A 500-kiloton airburst over Chelyabinsk and an enhanced hazard from small impactors." *Nature,*  503. 2013.

This is a rough estimate, and those authors note that the impact rate for asteroids of that size may not be constant.

"66 million years ago, a much larger object hit the Earth, causing a massive extinction."

For example, see Schulte et al., “The Chicxulub Asteroid Impact and Mass Extinction at the Cretaceous-Paleogene Boundary.” *Science* 327, 1214. 2010. 

They quote "~65.5" so I rounded up.

"75 percent of plant and animal species were lost, including, sadly, the dinosaurs."

For example, see Jablonski, D., "Extinctions in the fossil record." *Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B.,*  344, 11-17. 1994.

"It's taken 23 photos since I began speaking to you."

During the many, many times I practiced this talk, I generally said that line a few seconds past the four-minute mark. When I finally presented it, I spoke a little slower, for the version here 25 photos is more accurate.

"Astronomers are using every technique at their disposal to discover and study asteroids."

There's a tremendous amount of interesting scientific work done with asteroids, and I could only scratch the surface in this short talk. For example, radar astronomers study asteroids by bouncing radio waves off their surfaces. One of these radio telescopes (Goldstone) is shown in the slide behind me (beautiful photo by Douglas Ellison). Other specialists learn what minerals are on the surface of asteroids by examining their spectra. The book [*Asteroids IV*](http://geni.us/NvsO) (University of Arizona Press, 2015) contains summaries of the latest research and is written by leaders in the field.

"If we found a hazardous asteroid with significant early warning, we could nudge it out of the way."

A 1993 panel of experts concluded that there was sufficient technology to deflect an asteroid, if we had sufficient warning. Since then, technology has improved, but early warning is still needed. Because early warning is so vital, the priority now is to search the skies. To get a feel of what it would take to deflect an asteroid, see the [NASA/JPL NEO Deflection App](https://cneos.jpl.nasa.gov/nda/)

Canavan, G. H. and Solem, J. C. "Summary of workshop." *Proceedings of the Near-Earth-Object Interception Workshop,* ads. G. H. Genevan, J. C. Solem, and J. D. G Rather, Los Alamos; Los Alamos National Lab, pp 20-48. 1993.
